title: David’s background, interest in obesity, and focus on evidence
content: David Allison received his PhD from Hofstra University in 1990. He went on to complete his post-doctoral fellowship at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and a second post-doctoral fellowship at the New York Obesity Research Center at St. Luke’s Roosevelt Hospital Center. He’s currently the Dean and Provost Professor at the Indiana University Bloomington School of Public Health. David’s research interests include obesity and nutrition, quantitative genetics, clinical trials, statistical and research methodology, and research rigor and integrity. Peter admires the intellectual approach David has to obesity research, his lack of emotional thinking.

title: David's interest in the field of obesity
content: As an undergraduate, a sophomore at Vassar College in New York, he took a class on human emotion and motivation. He studied the theories of Stanley Schacter, who at the time was a professor of psychology at Columbia University; he is since deceased. Stanley was an amazing, brilliant man who wrote a book called Emotion, Obesity, and Crime. He talked about the connection among these and how the distinction between our cognitive state and our physiologic arousal state might lead us to certain kinds of behaviors, including in the case of some people, eating more calories than they might otherwise eat.

title: The moment when the obesity crisis was recognized, and the sloppy science that ensued
content: Looking at the data from the 1700s forward, there have been relatively steady increases in obesity rates in westernized industrialized countries since then. A wake-up moment occurred in the early ‘90’s with the NHANES III study.

title: The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
content: The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey is an annual study that surveys a representative sample of Americans with measured heights and weights to track obesity levels.

title: The Shift in Public Health Policy and Environmental Perspective
content: In the mid-90s, people like Kelly Brownell started to shift the public health policy and environmental perspective to think about prevention and children and the overall environment, the political, economic, social, food marketing environment we live in. It began to be seen as an environmental, social, political problem.

title: The Cause of Obesity Prior to NHANES III Study
content: Prior to the NHANES III study, there wasn't a single cause. What some people today call the energy balance model was accepted as valid, maybe not as a model but as a description of what occurs. There was a genetic component to obesity that smart people understood.

title: What Twin Studies Tell Us About the Genetics of Obesity
content: Twin studies tell us that there is a genetic component to obesity. Any rancher could have told you a hundred or more years ago that there's a genetic component. We can selectively breed animals for being thinner or fatter. It's prima facie evidence.

title: The Concordance of Obesity in Identical Twins
content: Peter asks, what is the concordance of obesity in identical twins separated at birth? For monozygotic (or identical twins) separated at or nearly after birth, it’s nearly the same magnitude as it is for twins reared together, which is around 0.8. He misspoke in the podcast when he said the concordance is 0.9 and asked us to correct this number to 0.8. Published in the International Journal of Obesity and Related Metabolic Disorders in 1996,  The heritability of body mass index among an international sample of monozygotic twins reared apart. Of course you can argue, well, that also takes into account the intrauterine environment, maybe some epigenetic things, but bottom line is whatever those things are, they’re not just child rearing of the home. Rearing of the home does have an influence, but it’s not huge. Peter notes, this is “an incredible degree of concordance”.

title: The History of Obesity Treatment
content: Peter notes when genetics play a role in disease, pharmacologic therapy makes sense. For example, if somebody is genetically predisposed to hypothyroidism, a doctor wouldn’t think twice about replacing thyroid hormone as necessary. The endocrine system is relatively straightforward to understand. Most of the focus was on developing tools to help people reduce energy intake. This is still the case today. Surgery and drugs mostly help people reduce calorie intake. Behavioral therapy began to be used in the ‘60’s. Stewart began thinking about using behavioral therapy to treat obesity. It has continued to get better and better since then. David’s sense is that we have been asymptoting for a long time. We’re getting incrementally better but not meaningfully better with many of the behavioral/cognitive things. In the early 90’s he was a postdoc at the New York Obesity Research Center. At this time a few people started using pharmaceuticals to treat obesity. Fen-phen is a drug that came up and caught people’s attention. We now know it’s dangerous and it’s gone. Fen-phen is a nickname for two drugs used in combination, phentermine and fenfluramine. Phentermine is a drug that was and still is approved by the FDA for the treatment of obesity. Though it’s never been approved for long-term. This goes back a long way, it’s a catecholaminergic agonist. It’s a relatively safe drug; no drug is perfectly safe.

title: Fen-Phen and the Investigation into Valvulopathy
content: Fenfluramine is a selective serotonergic reuptake inhibitor, which originally was used for depression and people realized sometimes those drugs (SSRIs) cause weight loss. Somebody realized you could put those two together and it seemed to provide better results. So that became a big craze. There were many unscrupulous medical providers who did provided it in ways they shouldn’t have. But there were many scrupulous medical providers who used it carefully and thoughtfully, and it did seem to have much better benefit than other people had predicted before. Then a very young, smart pathologist at the Mayo Clinic began noticing peculiar valvulopathy on autopsies. This was not a common thing. What they shared in common was the patients had been on fen-phen. This began the investigation into fen-phen. People quickly realized that fen-phen did produce a certain valvulopathy and further investigation made it clear it was the fenfluramine component, not the phentermine component that did that. So fenfluramine was withdrawn. Many drugs in the history of obesity hurt people; but what was good about this is prompted people to think more about obesity as a serious medical disorder.

title: Surgical Options for Obesity
content: David doesn’t know if there was a singular moment, rather it’s been sort of a steady march. There was 1 key step in the credibility of the surgical approach. The Swedish obesity study from Lars Sjostrom in Sweden. Published in the New England Journal of Medicine in 2004, Lifestyle, Diabetes, and Cardiovascular Risk Factors 10 Years after Bariatric Surgery. Surgery is the most effective life-saving, life-changing treatment we have, and it’s a good one. Many physicians had vitriolic battles on this topic. As more and more surgeries were performed, people got better at doing them, mortality rates went down and efficacy went up.

title: Effects of Surgery on Mortality Rate
content: Sjostrom showed more than a decade later in the New England Journal of Medicine that surgery reduced the mortality rate. Surgery had very powerful effects on obesity. It was clearly a life-saving and a beneficially, life-changing treatment. Since then, many other trials, some randomized, have been done showing positive benefits on many things, including longevity.

title: Reduction in All-Cause Mortality
content: Looking across studies, the risk reduction in all-cause mortality is on the order of a 50% reduction, sometimes a little more. David doesn’t know off the top of his head how this changes in patients with and without type 2 diabetes, but he shares the intuition that it is probably more beneficial for people with type 2 diabetes.

title: The Obesity Paradox
content: The phrase ‘Obesity Paradox’ has never been really crisply defined. People use it to mean at least 2 different things. There’s this so-called U-shaped curve, more accurately concave upward, it’s a bathtub shaped curve. So people at the very thin end also die earlier than people in the middle, just as people at the very heavy end die earlier. When people are sick or injured, obese people often live the longest. This is true even though obesity is associated with increased mortality rate or decreased longevity.

title: The U-shaped curve
content: Peter notes that this U-shaped curve gives an optimal BMI, a BMI associated with the lowest mortality. David suggests that instead of using 1 plot for everybody, graph it by decade. Mortality rates versus BMI at age 20 (red), 30 (green), 40 (yellow), 50 (purple), 60 (magenta), and 70 (blue).

title: The nadir of the bathtub shape concave upward curve
content: Under that mathematical model, David can show, in fact, that the point of BMI, the nadir of that bathtub shape concave upward curve, should keep moving to the right as you age, which is exactly what it does. They have a model that’s consistent with the data, but the data don’t prove their model. There are other models that would be consistent with it.

title: The speculation of weight increase
content: David tells a story that’s not perfectly true; it’s roughly true; it conveys the nice element of this. The average American might gain about a pound a year. For an average height, about 6 or so pounds might be a BMI unit. And so that might mean that over 6 years, you’d be about one BMI unit heavier. It’s almost as though your weight is increasing to keep you at the nadir, which is an interesting speculation.

title: BMI Touchstones
content: For those who are not used to BMI’s, here are some touchstones (see also the previous figure). The supermodel Kate Moss (at least a decades ago) had a BMI in 16 to 17 range. We say that about 18.5 is sort of the beginning of normal weight; less is underweight. David’s BMI right now is probably 21-ish. Bill Clinton’s BMI at the height of his presidency was probably 27, 28 (he’s since lost weight). Obesity begins around a BMI of 30. A top class Sumo wrestler has a BMI of about 43, 44. So it’s really 30, 32, where you see people 70, 80, and above, having that lowest mortality rate.

title: Interpreting BMI and Mortality Data and Considering Confounders
content: Peter wonders if there is a risk that we are looking at confounders here? Could affluence be a confounder? When body composition is taken into account, do you see the same thing? Some people have a BMI of 30 and fall into the obese category even though they only have 15% body fat; instead they are incredibly muscular. How do we reconcile, one, the potential confounders of that type of an analysis with this layer of granularity in the data that looks at adiposity versus lean mass? David notes this is the challenge of observational research in general. There are no simple solutions to it, other than trying to triangulate on the answer with multiple studies. What we really want are pure, randomized experiments in humans. With large samples and perfect compliance for many years. And we want to randomly assign people to be obese or not obese. Obviously, we can’t do that. What we have is  observational epidemiology. There are randomized trials where people lose weight. There are non-randomized trials, like Sjostrom’s with surgery. There are mouse studies. David includes them in his analysis. What they’ve shown is that throwing out subjects who die early in the analysis doesn’t help, or it doesn’t reliably help. What they showed is not that that confounding doesn’t occur. Confounding absolutely can occur and they think it’s likely.

title: David’s Early Work Analyzing BMI Data
content: When David went to analyze his first BMI mortality data set, he had no training in this. So he called up his friends to ask about it and ask for references to explain this. The epidemiologists would say “No, it’s obvious that it works”. David replied, “Well, it’s not obvious to me”. And they said, “Well, maybe you’re not smart enough to be an epidemiologist”. When he asked the statisticians about a paper that says you have to eliminate early death in the analysis, they would laugh and they replied, “That’s the most ridiculous thing I’ve ever heard. We don’t just throw out data and think it makes things better. You’ve got to have a model that you fit things to.”

title: BMI and Confounding Factors
content: David Allison looked at mathematical proofs, computer simulations, and meta-analysis to study confounding factors. Cutting people with diabetes, hypertension, and weight fluctuation out of the analysis wasn’t enough to flatten out the U-shaped curve. Katherine Flegal has written about how much is thrown away when subjects who die early are removed. Stigma from being overweight may have an effect. It’s likely that there’s confounding by cigarette smoking and socioeconomic status and stigma. Maybe it’s stigma that accounts for part of the increase in BMI associated with the lowest mortality over calendar time.

title: The Effect of Intervention on Longevity
content: The real important question is, what’s the effect of intervention? Don Rubin, a statistician at Harvard, developed the Rubin Causal Model. He is always asking, “What’s the intervention? If you say, does this cause that? What do you mean? Compared to what?” We are starting to see that some interventions do prolong life: surgery, SGLT-2 inhibitors, GLP-1 agonists, and so forth. David thinks this is the key question.

title: BMI and Body Composition
content: BMI is a measure of mass divided by stature. It was developed by Adolph Quetelet, who was a Belgian astronomer, epidemiologist, statistician, mathematician. Empirically, BMI works closer to the square for adult humans. Quetelet said, “Take mass or weight over stature squared, the square of stature”. Then it was called Quetelet’s Index. Now we call it BMI. It was rediscovered in the ‘60s or ‘70s by Ancel Keys, and termed BMI, body mass index.

title: BMI as a Clinical Tool
content: "BMI is a useful tool for epidemiologic research and some simple physiologic research and some simple clinical trials, it’s not a perfect clinical tool" – David Allison. For the average person, BMI works okay. Some people are skinny fat, they have a BMI of 26 but have metabolic syndrome, tons of visceral fat, very little muscle mass (see Ethnic Differences in BMI and Disease Risk). This is a different phenotype than perhaps what the model was built on. How much is the metric that we use for BMI validated in other ethnicities?

title: BMI and Ethnicity
content: Where a BMI of 20 to 25 is about perfect. 25 to 30 is overweight. 30 to 40 is obese. Then morbidly obese kicks in at some point. With a few exceptions, the idea that there’s a curve and that it’s a generally concave up curve. Yes, there are exceptions. The shape of that curve is not the same in every age, race, and sex group. It does seem that the right side (the part where you’re getting too high in BMI and risk is going up) seems to occur a lot earlier among people of Middle Eastern and East Asian descent. So this is very simple model to use just 1 curve for everybody. A slight more complicated models takes into account some of the other factors. Some groups have more visceral fat than the others for any given body mass index; and therefore it adjusts the curve.

title: Obesity and Ethnicity
content: "The narratives we have about obesity, including about ethnicity and obesity, are grossly oversimplified" – David Allison. So we often hear, “Obesity’s selectively a disease of the poor and uneducated”. In this country, it’s often stated, “Minority status leads to less income, less education, which in turn, leads to poorer access to healthcare, poorer habits, poorer living environments, which leads to poor health and reduced longevity”. And there’s probably some truth to that, but it’s not 1 to 1; it’s not simple. For example, when we hear that there’s this inverse relationship between socioeconomic status and obesity, this varies depending on ethnicity. We hear this over and over again. It was first shown by Mickey Stunkard, again, in the 1950s, in the Midtown Manhattan Project. It’s reliably true in adult white women. When you go outside the group of adult white women, it’s not always true. If you go to African American women, there is virtually no association between socioeconomic status and obesity. When you go to African American men and look at their obesity levels, they’re very similar to the obesity levels of European American men, white American men. But if you look at African American women’s obesity levels, and you compare it to European or white American women, it’s much higher. If you bring Hispanic Americans in, both men and women have higher levels of obesity, than do European American men and women. So in Hispanic Americans, there is an ethnicity difference (but not by gender). In African Americans, there is a gender by ethnicity difference. When you look at mortality, the African American curves follow similarly, but not identically, to the European American curves. But in Hispanic Americans, David’s research can’t find an association between BMI and longevity in this group. This is true across all BMIs. The data sets they have are not perfect; the follow-ups may not be long enough, the sample sizes may not be big enough. He’s not saying it’s causal, he’s only explaining what they observed in publicly available datasets of Hispanic Americans. Analysis of BMI and longevity could not show an association between elevated BMI and mortality in Hispanic Americans.

title: BMI vs Other Tools for Measuring Obesity
content: Peter's view of BMI is quite negative, as it offers little insight relative to other tools. Peter uses DEXA scans to provide 4 points of information: % body fat, visceral fat (VAT), bone mineral density, and Appendicular Lean Mass Index. VAT seems to be much more tightly correlated to what we see when we look at more sophisticated biomarkers of insulin sensitivity and metabolic health, and any evidence of liver fat. Peter wonders if at the population level, something better than BMI will come along one day.

title: 3D Photography for Measuring Body Composition
content: David published some work years ago on the idea of using 3D photography to measure body composition. Technicians who measured people’s body composition every day would say, “I can look at a person and tell you how much fat they have. And I’ll be very accurate.” David thought if they could do this with their eye, then he could do it with a camera. He got a NIH grant with Olivia Affuso and Steve Heymsfield to look at this; they published a paper on it, and since then many others have done it as well. He thinks Amazon may be working on this or already have something out on this; we’ll get to the point where we have 3D photography.

title: Fit for Purpose: Using the Right Tool for the Job
content: To measure mass there is: DEXA, plethysmography, isotope dilution techniques, etc. There’s this idea of fit for purpose. Similarly, if you were to say, “What proportion of that country has obesity?” BMI probably provides a reasonable estimate. But if you want to say, “I want to help this individual patient,” especially at the sort of the kind of artisan level that Peter goes at, then you need better tools.

title: Successful Approaches to Obesity
content: Successful approaches include: surgery, pharmaceuticals, and to some extent, individualized treatment, cognitive behavioral group-based treatment, including things like meal replacements and so on

title: Why Maintaining Weight Loss is Challenging
content: There is probably no single explanation. You can approach this from an evolutionary perspective, biochemical perspective; you can think about mechanisms. From the evolutionary point of view, for a long time, the meme was it’s the thrifty gene hypothesis from James Neel. The idea is that animals/ humans throughout evolutionary history have been on the brink of starvation. They did anything they could to preserve energy. When given the opportunity to get more energy, they ate as much as they could, while they could. Now in the modern environment, most of use over consume. David thinks this is simplistic for many reasons.

title: The Evolution of Sexual Reproduction
content: David compares the difficulty of maintaining weight loss to the evolution of sexual reproduction, which is still a mystery in biology. Sexual reproduction is inefficient from a genetic fitness point of view, but it allows for genetic diversity and adaptation to changing environments. The most compelling hypothesis for the evolution of sexual reproduction is the Red Queen Hypothesis, which suggests that organisms must constantly evolve to keep up with the rapidly evolving microbes in their environment.

title: The Inefficiency of Asexual Reproduction
content: Asexual reproduction is more efficient from a genetic fitness point of view, but it leads to a lack of genetic diversity. If humans used asexual reproduction, there would be much less genetic diversity and only a few hundred thousand gene pools. However, from an evolutionary perspective, selection occurs at the individual or gene level, and it has to make sense for that individual or gene's fitness.

title: The Thrifty Gene Hypothesis
content: Neel's thrifty gene hypothesis argues that humans need to be selected to get food when they can. This suggests that genes related to nutrition and metabolism have been under selection throughout human evolution.

title: Nutrition and Reproductive Fitness
content: If women get too thin, they stop menstruating. They may not die of starvation, but their reproductive fitness goes down.

title: Reasons for Eating More
content: Maybe not everybody was dying of starvation, but if you’re not getting enough food you may not be big enough to win the battle for mates in a polygyny physical combat mating system. That may select for wanting to eat more.

title: Safer Food Supply
content: Back in time before refrigeration and a modern, safe food supply, every time you ate something you were potentially exposed to microbes and toxins (not just predators). Eating less meant less exposure. But now with a safer food supply, this pressure is less.

title: Cooperative Living
content: Cooperative living is another angle; as a group it’s a bad situation if the members are so hungry all the time they are willing to kill each other for the last bite. It would be good to have some satiety mechanisms to preserve social order. Then everyone gets to eat a little and can work together to build tools and so on.

title: Differing Perspectives on Nutritional Epidemiology
content: There are 2 camps, 2 ends of the spectrum of views on nutritional epidemiology. 1) There’s a camp of people that would say there is absolutely nothing wrong with epidemiology, nutritional epidemiology. It is a masterful tool that provides exceptional insights without which we would be lost. 2) There are people who say this is a tool that has probably reached its peak of utility. The epidemiologists should probably focus on other problems outside of nutrition now. Peter is a little closer to this end of the spectrum.

title: David's Perspective on Nutritional Epidemiology
content: David feels this is a topic that needs more discussion. David doesn’t think that Gary Taubes, John, and Nina are naive and ignorant. David argues that findings of nutritional epidemiology often don’t hold up very well. When you really look, you see a lot of things that look like obfuscation, exaggeration, sweeping under the rug of measurement error, and so on. There are huge issues with confounding. There are huge measurement problems. Many people say the status quo is not okay. More change is needed than some minor fine-tuning. David believes reformation is essential; the status quo is completely unacceptable. But abolition is neither realistic nor desirable.

title: Nutrition and Observational Studies
content: It would be okay measured and controlled for all these things: food intake, diet composition, housing and socioeconomic status, genetic background. But you could never do this in humans. A mouse study illustrating the impossibility of fully controlling for confounds in observational studies. David ran a mouse study where he randomly assigned mice to eat different amounts of calories, but all on the same diet. What he found was the more calories he assigned the mice to eat, the shorter they lived. The interesting finding was with the ad libitum group. Within that group, some chose to eat more than others. Further, in this group they now have an observational epidemiologic study and can correlate amount chosen to be eaten with longevity.

title: Improving Observational Studies
content: David acknowledges that we may have to accept that we’re going to draw some inferences from something other than the pure classic pristine randomized control trial. But in between that and any old observational epidemiologic study, there’s a lot of space. There are better studies. Co-twin controls use identical twins and we randomly assign each to a different group. For example, randomly assign 1 twin to exercise a lot; their twin brother doesn’t exercise, but has the same genotype. How about observing interventions, even if they are not assigned at random. For example, build a restaurant in 1 town but not another. This is the realm of Bethany Bell, she looks at food deserts and things. Built a grocery store where there was a food desert and we’re told that food deserts are a problem, but it doesn’t look like things got better when we built the grocery store. That’s a much stronger design than just asking people how far away do you live from a grocery store?

title: Limitations of Nutritional Epidemiology
content: One reason why Peter struggles so much with the legitimacy of epidemiology has to do with food-frequency questionnaires. He simply can’t take seriously anything that relies on these questionnaires. For every patient he’s ever come in contact with, to try to accurately assess what they eat based on a food frequency questionnaire is a fool’s errand.

title: Issues with Nutritional Epidemiology
content: The hazard ratios that commonly show up in nutritional epidemiology studies and lead to grand statements are weak. Checking a food frequency questionnaire once in an 8-year study just doesn’t mean anything. This is the basis of an observation and a problem. Peter Attia suggests that there needs to be a referendum on how the media is taught how to interact with such studies and on how we scrutinize some of the methodologies behind these things.

title: Reforms Needed in Nutritional Epidemiology
content: David Allison notes that many people incorrectly perceive the problem in nutritional epidemiology to be a measurement issue. They agree that measurement of food intakes is a big problem but think everything else is fine. David thinks it’s important to look at the purpose of the self-reporting questionnaire. He thinks it’s important to have a greater level of honesty in the field and to be honest with ourselves and each other about what we know and don’t know and how we know it and don’t know it.

title: Honest Epistemic Humility
content: Simine Vazire just had a paper in one of the peer review journals, looking at or writing about epistemic humility and saying when you get to the discussion section of a paper and you consider that the hypothesis that you made, which now seems to be supported by your data, and you say, “but I might be wrong”. An honest epistemic humility would say, “I really might be wrong, and here’s all the ways I might be wrong that I and others should test going forward”. The battle shouldn’t be ad hominem. The battle shouldn’t be undercutting each other by who you are, and who you work for, and what your beliefs are. It needs to be a battle about the data.

title: Obesity Wars
content: David Allison notes that Katherine Flegal wrote a very famous paper about the obesity wars. Her meta-analysis published in 2005 found that BMIs in the overweight range were actually not strongly associated and consistently associated with increased mortality rate. In some cases, they were associated with a lower mortality rate. The media went crazy, responding as if this were a new finding. The new finding that there’s a genetic component to obesity was known decades ago.

title: Nutrition and Science
content: It may be pragmatic to say, “Oh, I trust Peter and he’s a smart guy. I know he studies a lot and he tells me I should eat this”, but it’s not science. The science is the data, the methods, and the logic connecting the data to conclusions; not whether I trust you or not.

title: Attacks in Nutrition
content: When Nina Teicholz had an editorial in Lancet, talking about some elements of nutrition, and fat, and carbohydrate, and many people wrote in trying to get it retracted. This sort of thing happens a lot in obesity and nutrition. People tried to get it retracted before it was published instead of just engaging with the data, the methods, and the logic.

title: Everyday Experience and Nutrition
content: David thinks this is because nutrition has to do with the everyday experience. All of us eat every day, almost all of us eat almost every day. Food is culture; it’s family; it’s love; it’s economy; it’s commerce; it’s political beliefs; it’s philosophical beliefs. It’s so connected to so many emotional things. We may mistake our experience for expertise.

title: Progress in Obesity
content: Amazing progress has been made on the surgical front and pharmacological front. It’s not clear why progress hasn’t been made on the nutritional front. A diet has not been found that reliably causes sustained weight loss. The big question— what diet results in sustained weight loss?

title: The Misconception of a Good Diet for Weight Loss
content: There is a misperception in the field around nutrition and weight loss or food intake and weight loss. That there is a good diet with respect to weight loss, such that for most people, if they just ate the right way, they wouldn’t have to count calories. They wouldn’t have to be uncomfortable and hungry. They wouldn’t have to feel deprived and yet would maintain a good, healthy weight. David has no reason to believe that’s true. There isn’t such a diet for many people. Now, for some people, they do maintain a normal, healthy, desirable weight without trying to restrict their energy, but maybe for others, it’s just not the case.

title: The Need for Better Obesity Treatments
content: We need to get on a much better path as a society making obesity treatments available to people. If you have cancer, we’re willing to treat you. If you have obesity, maybe not. If you’re rich, you can pay for that. If you’re not rich, what do you do?

title: The Stigma Surrounding Obesity
content: We’re on a good path on stigma, but there’s a long way to go. As a society, we’ve woken up to say stigmatizing obese people is not okay. Shaming people about their body habit is not okay. Sometimes the counterargument is, “But it’s good for them because it’ll help them want to lose weight.” And sometimes the argument made against the shaming is empirical. The evidence shows that people who experienced a lot of weight shaming gain more weight. Then the causal thing is thrown in, so therefore, you shouldn’t do it. It’s a moral issue; it’s not an empirical issue.

title: The Need for Better Science in Obesity Research
content: We know so much more about genes, and physiology, and metabolism, and cells with respect to obesity and nutrition than we knew 20, 30, 40 years ago. The one area where we are not making progress, and we aren’t yet on a good path, is with this public health community, school based, community based, policy based approach. We’ve got to clean up the quality of the science we do. We’ve got to start treating this like science. Just as much as the science of quirks, or tires on automobiles, or beta cells of pancreases. Treat it like real science and take it just as seriously.

title: The Problem with Cluster Randomized Trials
content: The cluster randomized trials we see in the childhood obesity literature bring to mind the phrase that rhymes with cluster muck. This is distorted evidence, this is science gone wrong in the worst sense. A cluster randomized trial is a trial which instead of randomizing the individual unit of observation (one person), entire intact units are assigned to one treatment or another. An individual might be a child in a school who you either assigned to the treatment group, maybe it’s exercise, or the control group, no special exercise. An entire intact unit might be a classroom, or a school, or a neighborhood, or a family.

title: Importance of Clustering and Nesting in Randomized Trials
content: One must analyze the data to take into account both what’s called the clustering and the nesting. The clustering is that you have people grouped and that grouping leads to more similar individuals. This has to be taken into account, so you need more than 1 cluster. People don’t do that reliably and they don’t do it correctly often, and that leads to many papers being wrong.

title: General Education as a Promising Intervention for Obesity
content: David believes that general education, especially for girls and women, leads to lower BMIs, lesser rates of obesity, and lesser diabetes than less education. There are studies in Europe of policies where someone puts in a policy and it effectively gives a cohort of people more education show this results in that cohort, less obesity, especially among women. The Moving to Opportunity Study funded by The Department of Housing and Urban Development took families who lived in so-called poor neighborhoods, and they randomly assigned them either to a control group, where they basically got nothing, or to a group where they received housing vouchers; but the housing vouchers required that they moved to less poor neighborhoods. What they found years later in follow up is that there was less obesity and diabetes in those assigned to move to the less poor neighborhoods and given the financial wherewithal to do so.

title: Peter Attia's approach to tackling obesity and diabetes
content: Peter Attia would divide the federal budget into 4 pots to tackle obesity and diabetes. The first pot is surgery, and it’s going to be both providing it and continuing to study it. The next one’s going to be pharmaceuticals, both providing it and continuing to study it. The third pot is going to be some general education, maybe general wellbeing, safety, security, starting in early childhood to see whether that alone is enough. And then the fourth pot would be basic research, basic science questions.

title: Reproducibility and Replicability in Science
content: David Sinclair was on a panel set up by the National Academy of Science, Engineering, and Medicine; they looked at the question of reproducibility in science. The phrase that Harvey Feinberg started using is— “no crisis but no cause for complacency”. The idea is that we must make things better. Peter asks how much of this situation is intrinsic to science itself and how much is a result of the media’s interface with science. David thinks both are important.

title: Normative and Non-normative errors in science
content: Michael Strevens book, mentioned earlier, (The Knowledge Machine) does a wonderful job explaining how hard science is. We have to make the distinction between normative errors and non-normative errors. Normative errors occur because of limitations in instruments/ technology used to study a phenomenon. Non-normative errors occur due to other factors. A very famous non-normative error is people working to determine the size of the thymus gland in children.

title: Nutrition-related non-normative errors in the past
content: The doctors irradiated undernourished kids with big thymus glands to prevent sudden infant death syndrome, which probably caused lots of cases of thyroid cancer because the thyroid and the thymus are very close to each other. This is an example of a non-normative error because it was bad sampling and bad inference from bad sampling.

title: Current non-normative errors in nutrition epidemiology
content: A lot of the errors in nutrition epidemiology today cannot be called normative errors anymore, these are non-normative. People are misanalyzing the cluster randomized trials, and they are not using professional statisticians when they need to. People are using food frequency questionnaires to draw causal inference about some of these things we have discussed, these are not normative errors, people should know better.

title: Rebuilding trust in science and differentiating between science and advocacy
content: David Allison thinks we need to be prepared to lose some battles in order to win the intellectual war. We need to be prepared to not use all the rhetorical tools at our disposal at any one point in time to convince somebody that X is true. We may be right about all those things, but if we use rhetorical devices, then we may win that battle may lose the war in helping people think though what good evidence is and elevating our level of dialogue. Scientists must not compromise the truth, and the standard is not so high for an advocate. Another important component is trust.

title: Peter's frustration with COVID discussions
content: COVID has been such a polarizing scientific phenomenon in a way that Peter has become quite frustrated in watching it. COVID has accelerated the loss of the public’s faith in science. Well-meaning public health officials have simply failed to communicate the nuance of science and lost so much credibility.

title: Trust in Nutrition Science
content: Trust in nutrition scientists is low compared to dieticians and medical doctors who talk about nutrition, and compared to other scientists.

title: Science vs Advocacy
content: The difference between science and advocacy can’t be overstated. The scientist hat is focused on the nuanced hard truth, as messy as it might be, as unclear as it might be, with no regard for how a person feels when they hear it and what action they may or may not take as a result of it. This is different from the advocacy hat— saying, “I want to change your behavior because I think it’s in your best interest.”
